review.title: How good is good enough? Re-evaluating the bar for energy disaggregation
review.abstract: Since the early 1980s, the research community has developed ever more sophisticated algorithms for the problem of energy disaggregation, but despite decades of research, there is still a dearth of applications with demonstrated value. In this work, we explore a question that is highly pertinent to this research community: how good does energy disaggregation need to be in order to infer characteristics of a household? We present novel techniques that use unsupervised energy disaggregation to predict both household occupancy and static properties of the household such as size of the home and number of occupants. Results show that basic disaggregation approaches performs up to 30% better at occupancy estimation than using aggregate power data alone, and are up to 10% better at estimating static household characteristics. These results show that even rudimentary energy disaggregation techniques are sufficient for improved inference of household characteristics. To conclude, we re-evaluate the bar set by the community for energy disaggregation accuracy and try to answer the question "how good is good enough?"

sections.heading: B. Data fusion to improve NILM accuracy
sections.text: De-aggregation in real homes poses several challenges, such as the presence of similar devices, multiple cases of the same devices, and the presence of energy-saving electronics. Recent work has focused on merging data from multiple ubiquitous sensors to improve the accuracy of NILM in such cases. Pathak et al. [25] and Saha et al. sections.text: Previous literature has argued that providing information at the device level can help end users reduce their energy consumption by up to 15% [12], but recently the applicability and usefulness of the energy breakdown has been called into question. sections.heading: V. CONCLUSIONS
sections.text: In this paper, we explored the question of how accurate NILM must be for it to be applicable in the real world. Our findings suggest that the breakdown of energy-consuming periodic background stresses such as HVAC and refrigerators unattended has a significant impact on applications such as predicting household characteristics. Our findings show that basic breakdown approaches are up to 30% better at estimating occupancy data than using aggregate current data alone and up to 10% better at estimating static household characteristics. Our findings show that even rudimentary energy breakdown techniques are sufficient to draw improved conclusions about household characteristics. Finally, we conclude that "how good is enough" can be answered through the lens of applications.

sections.heading: VI. LIMITATIONS AND FUTURE WORK
sections.text: Some of the household characteristics can be considered as continuous variables, and instead of treating the problem as a classification problem, we plan to view the problem as a regression problem.
